creditline: Gift of Gabriel P. and Yvonne M.L. Weisberg for the Weisberg Collection of European Drawings and Prints of the Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries
description: cat. 54; woman at L shoveling near well and barn; man at R raking; house at R in background; beige paper; light brown mat with simple light stained wood frame
medium: Brush and black ink, ink wash, charcoal, watercolor, and gouache with red crayon on tan paper laid down on board
text:
In 1905, Charles Milcendeau bought a farmstead in the heart of the Vendée marshes near his hometown of Soullans in western France. In this drawing, we see at left his modest house with its distinctive doorway, painted to look like a pointed stone arch. Before the house is a small pumphouse and basin. Part of the barn at right contained his studio. Trees of various maturities line the garden and fields. With some trees having brown leaves and others barren, plus patches of white that seem like the last vestiges of snow, it feels like the workers are engaged in an early spring cleanup.

To make this very personal drawing, Milcendeau combined various media, including ink, watercolor, gouache, crayon, and charcoal, all worked with consummate skill. Today the buildings serve as a small museum dedicated to his life and art.
title: Milcendeau's House at Bois Durand
